results.content:
My advice to the instructor is to describe what things (such as the function we are learning about) do instead of just saying out loud what you are typing next.  That is the difference between a course and a code-along.  This was a code-along.  

I could have easily taken the final code file supplied to me and just scrolled through it myself and gotten as much information as I did listening to you and coding along with you.

results.content:
This course is a very good introduction to the HTML Canvas and if it was named so I would give it 5 Stars.

As a master course it is lacking part of the Canvas API.
In addition it does not present any information regarding tools that exist in the market that will help you become a master of the Canvas.

Ben Fhala does a very good job explaining most of the concepts and the lessons are fun.

results.content:
Preconfigured.

Overall this is a good class if HTML5 canvas specifically is important to you.  The instructor really knows the material and does a great job of organizing the code and the canvases.  He does an OK job explaining the concepts.  Good enough for me - others may have issues.

I have a few minor issues as follows.

- The instructor touches upon canvas as a drawing construct vs canvas as an HTML element early in the course but doesn't follow through.  I was hoping for a little more detail.
- The labels displayed on the individual lessons (UL corner) are 1 section ahead.  Kind of annoying.

My other issues all have to do with the provided code.  First the abrupt start on said code in lesson 2, then the occasional discrepancy between the code I had and the code the  instructor was using.  

As an example, in lesson 1 I had to track down and correct a style for the canvas before my Palau looked like what I saw in the lesson.

But even with those headaches, still a pretty good class for HTML5 canvas.
